abuse: Excessive attention to personal goals; unrealistic expectations of others.
emotions: He wants to keep up with others in terms of effort and technical performance.
fear: Being too predictable; not be recognized as an “expert”.
influence_others_by: Confidence in your ability to hone new knowledge; by developing and following “correct” procedures and actions.
its_value_for: Skilled at solving technical and human problems; professionalism in his specialty.
judge_others_by: Your self-discipline; their positions and promotions.
more_effective_if: Collaborate genuinely for general benefit; delegate important tasks to the appropriate people.

The professional values ​​skill in specialized areas. His enormous desire to “excel at something” leads him to careful control of his own performance at work. Although his goal is to be “the” expert in a certain area, the Professional gives the impression of knowing a little of everything. This image is more marked when it puts into words the knowledge it has on various topics.

In his relationship with others, the Professional usually projects a relaxed, diplomatic and affable style. This attitude can suddenly change in your area of ​​expertise when you focus too much on achieving high levels of performance. By assessing self-discipline, the Professional evaluates others based on their self-discipline, which is measured by their daily performance. Your expectations in relation to yourself and to others are high. He usually expresses his disappointment.

While his nature asks him to focus on developing an organized job proposition and increasing his own abilities, The Professional also needs to help others hone their talents. In addition, you need to know how to better appreciate those who contribute to the work effort, even if they do not use what the Professional considers the “correct method”.
under_pressure: It is self-conscious; sensitive to criticism.
